message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, cough, dyspnea, angina, and elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme suggests sarcoidosis, which is a type IV cell-mediated (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction. None of the other options fit the clinical presentation of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme, and symptoms of cough, dyspnea, and angina, suggest sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy along with elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme levels suggest that the patient has sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a type IV cell-mediated (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are IgE-mediated, Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve cytotoxic antibodies, and Type III hypersensitivity reactions involve immune complex deposition. Type III and IV reactions may occur together, but sarcoidosis is primarily a Type IV reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and results suggest the patient has sarcoidosis, which is a type IV (cell-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are immediate (e.g., anaphylaxis), type II is antibody-mediated cytotoxic reactions, and type III is immune complex-mediated reactions. Type III and IV mixed reactions can occur in some diseases, but sarcoidosis is primarily a type IV reaction.

Sarcoidosis is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which is cell-mediated (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction. Options A, B, and D are not correct because they do not match the mechanism of reaction in sarcoidosis.
